fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Expressing the sheaf condition using Lawvere–Tierney operators, we only need to show for dense subobjects F \hookrightarrow G that \hom(G, X^Y) \to \hom(F, X^Y) is a bijection. This is equivalent to \hom(Y \times G, X) \to \hom(Y \times F, X). Note that the subobject Y \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times G corresponds to the characteristic function Y \times G \to G \to \Omega. Hence the denseness of F \hookrightarrow G implies the denseness of Y \times F \hookrightarrow Y \times G. Since X is a sheaf, we conclude that X^Y is also a sheaf.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dense subobject of a Lawvere–Tierney operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator j, a subobject F \hookrightarrow G is j-dense if G \to \Omega \xrightarrow{j} \Omega is the constant true. In terms of the corresponding J \hookrightarrow \Omega, we need the pullback of it with G \to \Omega to be {\textrm{id}} : G \to G.

Knowing the correspondence of Grothendieck coverages on {\mathcal{C}} and Lawvere–Tierney operators on {\mathsf{Psh}}({\mathcal{C}}), we naturally want to rewrite the sheaf condition to use Lawvere–Tierney operators instead of Grothendieck coverages.

Recall that the sheaf condition requires for every covering sieve S \hookrightarrow \mathop{\mkern{-2mu}\text{よ}\mkern{-2mu}}(U) that the composition \hom(\mathop{\mkern{-2mu}\text{よ}\mkern{-2mu}}(U), X) \to \hom(S, X) is an isomorphism. We can reify this to a definition.
Given a class of arrows S, an S-local object is an object X such that for every f : A \to B in S, the composition map \hom(B, X) \to \hom(A, X) is an isomorphism.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Dense subobject of a Lawvere–Tierney operator

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator j, a subobject F \hookrightarrow G is j-dense if G \to \Omega \xrightarrow{j} \Omega is the constant true. In terms of the corresponding J \hookrightarrow \Omega, we need the pullback of it with G \to \Omega to be {\textrm{id}} : G \to G.

In terms of sieves, for every section s \in {\Gamma}(U, G), the sieve of arrows on U along whom the restriction of s is in F must be a covering sieve. We have arrived at the desired reformulation of the sheaf condition.
Given a Lawvere–Tierney operator j, a j-sheaf is defined as a j-local object, i.e. a local object under the j-dense monomorphisms.
Here are the unfinished trees. The links not written is also shown in the backlinks section.

The associated simplicial fiber bundle of twisted products admits a simpler description. Suppose we have simplicial sets F, B, a simplicial group G with an action G \times F \to F and a twisting function \tau on B. The associated twisted product B \times_\tau F is defined exactly the same as twisted products, except we replace the factor G with F. This still makes sense, because we can interpret the multiplication \tau(b) \cdot \partial_n f as the G-action.

In particular, if we consider G as a simplicial set with a G-action on the left via multiplication, then the associated twisted product B \times_\tau G is exactly the same as the twisted product B \times_\tau G, which explains our identical notation.

Given a pair of chain reductions \rho : C \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow D and \rho' : C' \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow D', we can construct a reduction from the mapping cone \operatorname{Cone}(f) of a chain map f : C \to C' to (the action of \rho on f).

This is a set of notes on effective homology and algebraic topology. Main references are Constructive Homological Algebra and Applications and Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology. We assume basic familiarity with the classical aspects of the theory, although there will also be links within this forest to the relevant concepts.

fr:ul.fr:li: W-bar construction, simplicial principal bundles, twisted products by Simplicial objects in algebraic topology
composition of strong homology equivalence, tensor product, cone, bicomplex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Any small abelian category can be realized as a full abelian subcategory of a category of left R-modules for some ring R.
